title: Lending on the Eve of Mandatory Forgiveness
vignette: A statute will wipe certain loans in six months. Should a credit-union issue new consumer loans that will likely be erased?

options.text: Refuse the loan; protect your assets.
Lend anyway, trusting the borrower's need outweighs the risk.

title: Filing an Opt-Out From Debt Amnesty
vignette: Lenders can file a court transfer that exempts their loan from the upcoming cancellation program. Use the loophole or honour the spirit of the amnesty?

options.text: File the document; retain the right to collect.
Do not file; let the debt be cancelled.

title: Voluntary Repayment After Legal Discharge
vignette: A graduate's student loan was forgiven by law. Should she still repay her alma mater out of gratitude, or keep the money?

options.text: Repay out of moral duty.
Keep the money; the law released you.

title: Commercialising Fallow-Year Harvest
vignette: Government orders farms to leave land fallow and let anyone pick. A grower considers selling truck-loads of the volunteer produce. Legit or against the program's intent?

options.text: Sell freely; income sustains your family.
Limit to small, symbolic sales or give it away.

title: Fencing a Public-Access Orchard
vignette: During the same fallow season, an orchard owner debates installing temporary fencing to limit crowds vs leaving gates open for public picking.

options.text: Fence it; safeguard produce and trees.
Leave it open; let anyone pick freely.

title: Private Stock After Commons Season Ends
vignette: Rules say once wild pickings of fallow-year produce disappear, stored produce should be shared or discarded. May a household keep its frozen surplus?

options.text: Keep it; private stores are your right.
Remove or distribute it as required.

title: Bartering regulated produce for higher-value goods
vignette: Someone trades produce from the public-harvest year for superior produce, pocketing the gain.

options.text: Trade; maximise value within legal bounds.
Avoid trade; consume it in its original form.

title: Converting regulated produce into cash
vignette: A seller swaps fallow-year wine for money, transferring its restrictions to the cash. Can the money now be spent like ordinary funds?

options.text: Use the cash for ordinary purchases.
Spend it only on items eaten with the same restrictions.

title: Feeding regulated produce to animals
vignette: Left-over public-harvest greens are still fit for people. May the household feed them to animals instead?

options.text: Give them to the animals; nothing wasted.
Reserve them for human consumption only.

title: Leasing farmland to outsiders during a mandated rest year
vignette: An owner considers renting fields to an external operator so cultivation continues during the required fallow year.

options.text: Lease it; maintain an income stream.
Refuse; preserve the land's mandated rest.

title: Paying Workers With Commons Produce
vignette: A community group harvests freely available berries. May organisers pay pickers with portions of those berries instead of cash?

options.text: Permitted – payment in kind is fair and keeps costs down.
Forbidden – regulated produce may not be used as a wage commodity.

title: Selling regulated produce by weight versus estimate
vignette: Vendors wish to sell public-harvest oranges by precise weight to satisfy urban customers, instead of by loose estimation encouraged by guidelines.

options.text: Allow precise weighing – ensures honest trade.
Prohibit weighing; only informal measures keep commerce modest.

title: Feeding regulated produce to outsiders' animals
vignette: A household with surplus public-harvest greens wonders if it may give them to a neighbour's livestock, even though the food carries usage restrictions.

options.text: Yes; better use than waste.
No; restricted food is for designated human consumption only.
